conclusion.title: A formal definition of a matrix
conclusion.p: To formally define a matrix requires a notion of a field, which is a particularly strong algebraic object. The model of a field is the set of rational numbers with the operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by nonzero numbers. Once the field axioms are satisfied for a particular set, there are a further set of axioms which define a vector space over the field. The behavior of matrices with elements from a given field is directly tied to the concept of a linear transformation of a vector space over that field. For an online introduction to matrix theory, vector space theory, and linear algebra, see the online beta version of Dr. Rob Beezer's First Course in Linear Algebra.
